|International African Association
| rowspan="4" |Blue background emblazoned with a central yellow five-pointed star
| rowspan="4" |The blue background symbolises the Congo River and the yellow star (which is still used) symbolises both unity, and a bright future. It was the only flag used during the entire period of colonial Belgian administration.

| rowspan="2" |First Congolese Republic
|An additional six yellow five-pointed stars are added to the hoist
|The added stars represent the six state provinces existing at the time of independence from Belgium.
|-
| rowspan="2" |
| align="center" |1963–1964
| rowspan="2" |A yellow five-pointed star sitting alongside a red and gold bend sinister on a blue background
| rowspan="2" |The red bend represents the blood of martyrs, and the gold frame represents the riches of the land.
|-

|Republic of Zaire
|Light green emblazoned with a yellow circle containing an arm holding a red torch
|Filled with Pan-African colours, the flag has a central emblem which is that of the Popular Movement. The torch symbolises the spirit of revolution and the lives of dead revolutionaries.
